text: from the outside world these are seen as
journalists who are doing their jobs and
they were arrested and put on trial and
convicted to a very long term in Egypt
however this is very politicized and it
comes amid standoff that's been going on
for quite a long while between the
Egyptian government and the Qatari
government which owns the al-jazeera
satellite channels and Al Jazeera is
seen by many in Egypt and by Egyptian
officials as a mouthpiece for the Muslim
Brotherhood and this is what the
accusations were about supporting the
Muslim Brotherhood's and spreading lies
that with with the aim of tarnishing the
reputation of the state of Egypt as said
by the prosecution so what will what
will happen now is probably there will
be an appeal and the important thing is
that the newly elected president of
Fattah el-sisi has the power to pardon
them well from you saying that I mean
it's very difficult for us to call the
shots here isn't it we don't know
exactly what people are thinking here
but there would be a sense in which it
would be important for the government
perhaps for al Sisi that justice be seen
to be done although many would say that
the evidence against these individuals
was pretty flimsy stuff and that then
perhaps politics can kick back into gear
and they could be released what
relatively quickly I mean I suppose it's
a hope now if now that they have been
convicted so they're likely to remain in
jail unless we see a decision to release
them on grounds of health or otherwise
at least on bail but so far throughout
the trial they have not been granted
bail even though repeat repeatedly the
clay the claim the request for bail has
been made so what will happen now is
that their lawyers will launch an appeal
they will probably ask for for them to
be released on bail we'll see what will
happen on that and we'll see if there's
will be any intervention from the
president
